ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this course definitely. The novels, short stories, play, and poems on the syllabus are mostly interesting works, make certain you have enough time up until midterm to read a novel a week. But be prepared to look at stereotypical Italian-American portrayals in film and television. Contribution includes: Reading journal throughout the semester, short essays for at least seven of the readings, attendance at weekly screenings, heavy in-class participation reviewing the literature (tues.) and film (thurs.), a midterm paper, a final exam of short essays and two long essays, and a final paper.

One of the best classes I have taken at Yale, for sure. I learned a lot and got to read/watch awesome books/films. Doing work for this class always felt like getting away from doing work, and then class discussions made me see a greater depth to each of the works.

This class is so wonderful, you will NOT regret taking it. Yes, class will be three days a week, but one of those is spent just watching movies. Class discussion is great, the books are pretty good, and I loved all but a couple of the movies. The coursework is very manageable, and the real plus of this class is that it's taught by Professors Marcus and Papallo -- take it just to have a class with them!

Yes! The course was very enjoyable. Great films, interesting novels/stories/poems as readings, good class discussions and very manageable assignments. I also appreciated not having laptops or phones out in class, and having only 7 people in it, it was much more engaging that way! The walking tour and pizza at the end was also nice and allowed us to think of Italian-American life as 'tangible."

This is a really interesting look at different authors’ and filmmakers’ perceptions and portrayals of the Italian American experience. This is not a history class, it is very much about analyzing artistic and storytelling devices, but Penny and Taylor threw in a lot of historical context that really helped my understanding of the subject matter. At least this year, the reading was heavily front-loaded, so you’ll be reading a novel a week (later it trickled down to several poems or short stories) as well as watching a film a week. I found the work aspects of the class really fun, and wanted to spend time writing the two short essays. A lot of people in the class were of Italian descent, so I guess it helps to have a narcissistic interest in it, but if you’re looking for a fun literature/film analysis class about Italian Americans, with some really sweet professors, take this class!
